prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Coordination with state court proceedings

para.paratext: The Panel has considered the potential for coordination of pretrial proceedings, particularly discovery, between the transferred federal court actions and related state court actions. If the potential exists for coordinating these actions, the federal district in which the state court actions are pending will be favored.[1]

This factor may be significant. In one air crash case, the Panel transferred cases to a district other than that where the crash occurred largely because there was an opportunity to coordinate state and federal court proceedings if transfer were made to a different district.[2]

This factor is potentially a very compelling factor in selection of a transferee district. If state court litigation is concentrated in a single state, the opportunity to coordinate state and federal proceedings should be a powerful force favoring that forum as a transferee district. The inability to coordinate federal cases and state cases in multiple states is recognized as a singular weakness in the Panel's authority.[3] The opportunity to coordinate with pending state-court criminal cases can also be a compelling factor for the Panel.[4] Even proximity to criminal proceedings (as in an adjacent jurisdiction) may be compelling to the Panel.[5] In one docket the Panel transferred to the District of Maryland because the “[w]ave of putative statewide class action lawsuits relating to the PAX system began with an action removed to the District of Maryland.”[6]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
